;三周前，温柔的巨兽抵达西贡海域，让香港人兴奋不已和兴趣。这头鲸鱼被认为是布氏鲸，随后在牛尾海地区觅食和嬉戏，四周环绕着派对游艇、快艇和寻求刺激的观光客，偶尔会表演壮观的进食策略，让旁观者惊叹不已。

;<但是，7月31日，随着鲸鱼尸体的发现，这个故事以悲剧告终。虽然死亡原因仍在调查中，尸检小组在鲸鱼的背鳍前面发现了新的伤口。

;

;在最初看到鲸鱼后，保护组织多次表达了对鲸鱼安全的担忧。随意的“赏鲸之旅”和附近普遍繁忙的海上交通令人担忧。

;

;当公众呼吁停止骚扰鲸鱼失败时，政府被要求进行干预。代表们表示，他们在现有法律框架内已尽力，但表示许多建议并不可行。

;

;环境生态局局长谢展云在参观尸检现场后承诺，政府将采取行动“通过审查现有立法、加强公众教育以及为未来鲸鱼到来制定应急计划，“未来更好、更快、更有效”。

;

;记录显示，香港周边海域曾是多只须鲸的栖息地。物种：2007 年的一项研究表明，布氏鲸在香港及其周边地区可能并不那么罕见。对中国鲸鱼分布的研究还表明，广东附近海域曾经是须鲸的热点地区。

;

;这些记录表明鲸鱼可能会再次造访香港，这引发了一个重要问题：香港如何提供为海洋巨型动物提供更安全的避难所？

;

;从最新的新闻报道来看，政府希望加强公众教育，探索规范观鲸活动的机制，这是积极的一步。海外有很多例子和案例可供参考。

;

;牛尾海疯狂的两周追鲸活动暴露了一些突出问题。我们看到许多香港人对野生动物的态度和行为常常不恰当；我们在保护野生动物方面的法律法规不足；即使在农村水域，海上交通量也很大；鲸鱼在进食时捕获的猎物数量微乎其微。

;

;这些问题引发了一个更广泛的问题。我们怎样才能使香港成为一个对海洋哺乳动物和本地生物多样性更安全、更有吸引力的地方？

;

;世界自然基金会香港分会相信健康的海洋生态系统就是答案。需要紧急采取两个关键步骤。首先，建立更多的海洋保护区——这有助于补充枯竭的海洋生物种群，并提供合法手段来控制与海洋保护不相容的用途。

;

;香港政府需要迅速采取行动，扩大现有的保护区目前仅占当地水域的 5%。牛尾海是鲸鱼度过最后几天的地方，是世界自然基金会香港分会的海洋保护优先热点之一。如果它是一个保护区，这个故事会有不同的结局吗？

;

;其次，海洋空间规划是一种越来越流行的用于可持续管理海洋空间的工具。作为全球最繁忙的港口之一，平衡香港的发展需求与环境保护需求一直是一项挑战。

;

;然而，中华白海豚数量急剧下降，以及即将实施的滘河建设计划宜洲人工岛应该足以推动政府优先开展全市范围的海洋空间规划研究。

;

;香港小组发现，渡轮数量减少会导致海豚活动增多

;

;这将为主要海洋利益相关者提供一个平台，让他们分享想法并制定有益于社会和自然环境的明智、协调的计划。

;

;世界自然基金会香港分会正在启动一项海洋核算试点研究，有望为这一长期目标带来动力——迟来的努力。我们欢迎大家加入我们这项艰巨而重要的任务。

;

;牛尾鲸重新激发了香港人的海洋和鲸类保护意识。这个悲惨的故事现在应该点燃保护我们脆弱的海洋生态系统的决心和行动，以便有一天我们能够尊重和安全地欢迎所有鲸鱼。

;周五，数千人混乱地占领了纽约联合广场及周边街道这是一位受欢迎的直播主宣布“赠品”活动后的场景，警方奋力阻止粉丝投掷弹丸并伤害警察。

;

;该活动由 Kai Cenat 推广，他因在游戏网站上进行直播而闻名Twitch 和 YouTube 视频。

;

;他早些时候在其 Instagram 帐户上宣布下午 4 点在曼哈顿公园举行“巨额赠品”。

;

;活动开始前，新闻直升机的镜头向人们展示了投掷瓶子和椅子，爬上地铁入口的屋顶，站在汽车顶部并卸下灭火器。

;

;纽约市警察局最高级别的制服警官杰弗里·马德雷 (Jeffrey Maddrey) 告诉我们记者称，警方正在审问塞纳特，并且可能对他提出指控，包括煽动骚乱。

;

;马德雷表示，逮捕的总人数尚不清楚，但警方已经在一辆城市公交车上装满了被拘留的人。多名警官和与会者受伤；马德雷说，他自己被物体击中。

;

;“公园里的人开始对警察和公众实施暴力行为，”他在新闻发布会上说。 “我们的军官遭到袭击。我们被压垮了，我们被推了。”

;

;一些人燃放烟花，另一些人则挥舞着建筑工地的工具，Maddrey 说。目前尚不清楚是什么引发了混乱。

;

;IPO 透露，这个直播平台上的大多数直播主并没有赚到一分钱

;

;来自电视新闻直升机的视频显示塞纳特穿着黑色衣服有一次，这辆SUV把头伸出天窗，人们围住了这辆车。

;

;汽车开走时，至少有一个人从车上摔下来。

;

;在一段视频中在周四发布的帖子中，塞纳特告诉他的粉丝，赠品将包括电脑和 PlayStation 5 游戏机。

;

;塞纳特今年 21 岁，在 Twitch 上拥有 650 万粉丝，在 YouTube 上拥有 400 万订阅者。他在 2022 年 Streamy Awards 上被评为“年度主播”。

;地方和联邦机构对位于墨西哥的非法医疗仓库进行了长达数月的调查加州中部的一座建筑据称藏有潜在的病原体，由一家与中国有联系的公司运营。

;

;弗雷斯诺县里德利市政府官员表示，在 3 月份对该建筑进行定期检查时，他们发现了出现的情况并联系了县卫生部门、州公共卫生部和联邦调查局。

;

; 县卫生部门在 3 月至 7 月期间向加利福尼亚州弗雷斯诺县高等法院提交的文件将该地点描述为“构成公害”，并寻求进入该地点的许可，以“减少传染病、传染源、和其他生物材料”。

;

;弗雷斯诺县卫生部门支持这一请求，并补充说，在 3 月份的第二次​​检查中，州卫生官员“记录了被禁运的医疗设备，例如 Covid 测试和妊娠测试，据信是开发的

;

;此外，该县机构表示，当地卫生官员“观察了血液、组织和其他体液样本；血清；现场还发现了数千瓶未标记的液体和可疑生物材料。

;

;“还发现了各种实验室设备，包括生物安全柜和离心机。法庭文件显示，还观察到了低温储藏室”，并补充说，“发现了一个房间，里面容纳了数百只实验室小鼠”。

;

;联邦卫生与公众服务部还报告称，“至少有 20 只可能存在现场发现了包括冠状病毒、艾滋病毒、肝炎和疱疹在内的传染源。

;

;一项市县联合调查确定，该建筑的租户是一家名为 Prestige BioTech 的内华达州生物技术公司，该公司没有获得许可在加利福尼亚州做生意。该仓库自 2022 年 10 月起就在那里运营。

;

;下一次大流行？世卫组织正在制定需要观察的病原体清单

;

;根据法庭文件，一位名叫 David He 的人代表 Prestige Biotech 与调查人员进行了沟通。文件中的电子邮件显示，他对该房产中储存有传染性病原体提出质疑。

;

;“我们非常认真地对待此事，”他在 6 月 7 日的一封电子邮件中写给弗雷斯诺县卫生部门。“请告诉我们尽快拿出相关调查结果和证据。因为在我们掌握的物品和信息清单中，我们没有发现任何对公众健康有害的传染源。”

;

;《南华早报》致电何先生，但无人接听。

;

;但在向法院提交的一份声明中，里德利法典执行官杰萨琳·哈珀 (Jesalyn Harper) 表示，她已与一位名叫 Xiuquin Yao 的女士交换了电子邮件，该女士自称是 Prestige Biotech 的总裁。

;

;姚，哈珀说， “表示该财产被用来储存与开发诊断测试套件相关的生物医学用品，以及饲养大量专门饲养的用于免疫学和肿瘤学相关测试的小鼠”。

;

;Harper补充说，姚没有提供任何州或联邦机构允许在该地产上进行活动的任何证明或许可证。

;

;“她也没有提供照顾老鼠的计划，或者老鼠会在哪里由于该建筑在市政府检查后被贴上红色标签，因此将被搬迁”。

;

;根据法庭文件，姚表示，在环球公司腾出另一家公司后，Prestige BioTech 转移了属于一家现已解散的加州公司环球医疗科技 (Universal Meditech) 的资产。仓库在县城。调查人员将 Prestige Biotech 描述为环球公司的继任者。

;

;多家当地新闻媒体报道 Prestige Biotech 是一家中国公司，但调查人员尚未证实这一点。

;

;文件没有明确说明是否姚是中国公民或华裔美国公民。

;

;苏丹军队夺取储存病原体的实验室，“生物危害风险很高”

;

;在接受《加州环球报》采访时，当地一位出版物中，哈珀说姚告诉她，她住在中国，只能通过电子邮件进行交流。

;

;“然后她请了一位顾问，但我们仍然无法确定 Prestige Biolabs 还是 Universal Meditech 是哈珀说。

;

;在其他法庭文件中，当地卫生官员确实表示，虽然在现场发现了老鼠，但“现场没有证据表明这些老鼠正在被注射或测试” ”，并补充说“老鼠处于困境中”。

;

;卫生官员称，调查人员发现“笼子里有大量死亡老鼠，并且观察到老鼠有许多受伤和畸形”。

;

; p>;

;“由于观察到动物遭受的痛苦，并且缺乏为老鼠提供足够住房和照顾的能力”，773 只老鼠被兽医“人道安乐死”。

;

;本周已到达县卫生部门助理主任乔·普拉多 (Joe Prado) 表示，可能对公众构成危险的生物危害品和化学物质仍在从该设施中清除。

;

;“现场有 800 多种化学物质，我们正在清除这些化学物质。”他在接受采访时表示：“我们与联邦环保局合作，以便能够按照联邦和州标准处置这些化学品。”

;

;当地共和党人批评这些机构没有向公众通报涉嫌实验室的情况。及时。

;

;“公共卫生部门意识到了这一点……现在已经过去五个月了。除了当地媒体的一名记者报道此事外，公众并没有获悉此事。这对我来说是不可接受的……对我们的选民来说也应该是不可接受的”，弗雷斯诺市议会成员加里·布雷德菲尔德 (Garry Bredefeld) 本周表示。

;所有人的目光都集中在台湾亿万富翁郭台铭身上，看他是否会宣布竞购访问美国回国后竞选总统 — — 此举肯定会给主要反对派阵营在一月份关键的选举中带来麻烦。

;

;但这是否意味着领跑者威廉将明显获胜执政的民进党候选人赖清德的表现还有待观察，分析人士表示，距离投票还有五个月的时间，现在下结论还为时过早。

;

;郭台铭今年早些时候，未能赢得主要反对党国民党 (KMT) 的提名，但有关其仍可能参选的猜测仍在继续。

;

;这位富士康创始人在过去两个月里异常活跃，访问台湾各地，参加当地政客的竞选集会，并就他对台湾未来和台湾人民福祉的愿景发表演讲和声明。

;

;即使在国民党于7月下旬证实之后不会改变提名新北市长侯裕义为总统候选人的决定，尽管他在竞选中表现相对较差，但没有任何迹象显示郭台铭放弃竞选。

;

;“这次访问，我将与专家和智库学者会面……就如何让台湾远离战争、永久维护和平征求他们的意见。”7月30日，郭台铭在启程前往美国开始为期10天的访问之前表示。他预计8月9日回来。

;

;“我也想让我的美国朋友明白，台湾的主流观点是‘和平不要战争’，台湾不想成为下一个乌克兰， ”他在脸书发文写道。

;

;郭台铭表示，因为使命感，他不后悔与志同道合的朋友一起“把台湾从战争边缘拉回和平之路”。 ”——尽管不断遭到对手的言语攻击和抹黑。

;

;为了对抗民进党领导的台独绿营，他还呼吁主要反对派结成大联盟，其中包括国民党、台湾人民党和其他反对绿营的人士。

;

;“未来，我将继续走遍台湾的每一片土地……为确保无论谁坚持两岸和平、经济繁荣和政治廉洁......都能够赢得[总统]选举。

;

;分析人士接受了郭台铭对结盟的呼吁以及他的主张。誓言为台湾带来和平，强烈表明他竞选总统的愿望。

;

;“与他上个月在《华盛顿邮报》上发表的评论文章相比，郭台铭的言论读起来更像是他的宣言花莲国立东华大学政治学教授石成峰说。

;

;郭台铭在 7 月 17 日发表的评论文章中，将民进党及其总统候选人赖智比为“总统竞选”的先兆。战争，其反北京政策使两岸紧张局势达到历史最高水平。

;

;北京将台湾视为其领土，必须将台湾置于其控制之下，必要时可以使用武力。

;

; >;

;郭台铭的专栏暗示他并未排除台湾参选总统的可能性：分析人士

;

;自民进党蔡英文于 2016 年当选总统并拒绝接受选举以来，两岸紧张局势加剧北京的一个中国原则。

;

;因此，北京暂停了两岸会谈和与台湾的官方交流，同时通过在该地区举行军事演习和挖走台湾的盟友来加大对台北的压力。与大多数国家一样，美国作为台湾最大的非正式盟友和武器供应国，不承认台湾是一个独立国家，但反对单方面以武力改变两岸现状。

;

;施说侯在各种民意调查中相对较差的表现让郭台铭有动力说服国民党支持者，他可以在竞选中表现更好。

;

;“但如果郭台铭加入竞选，将使一月份的选举成为一场四人角逐。这可能会分裂反对派的选票并使赖智受益。”他补充说，国民党不太可能用郭台铭取代侯，因为主要反对党已经确认新北市长为其提名人。

;

;目前，角逐共有三名竞争者，民进党的黎智英领先于TPP的前台北市长柯文哲和国民党的侯。

;

;据意见民意调查显示，黎智英的支持率维持在 33-36% 左右，高于柯的 28-30% 和侯的 21-24%。

;

;如果郭台铭参加竞选，黎智英的支持率将达到根据在线媒体机构 Newtalk 周二的民意调查，柯氏的支持率为 30.46%，柯氏为 24.71%，郭台铭为 17.34%，侯孝贤为 16.92%。

;

;周三，柯在接受电视采访时表示如果郭台铭竞选总统，黎智英一定会获胜。

;

;“我的获胜机会为零，”他谈到自己获胜的机会时说道。 “三位[反对派]候选人[他、侯和郭]全部都会失败，而赖以百分百获胜。”

;

;国立太阳大学政治学教授廖大吉高雄中山大学也同意，如果郭台铭也参与其中，柯氏的处境将会更加艰难。

;

;在谈到不喜欢民进党或国民党的年轻选民时，她说：“郭台铭的选票与柯氏的选票重叠，如果郭台铭参加竞选，柯氏的竞争将会更加激烈。”

;

;廖说，作为一名成功的商人，郭台铭正在接近他的政治目标”

;

; Sat, 05 Aug 2023 04:50:02 +0800 How Thailand can draw closer to China despite US rivalry and geopolitical tensionshttps://www.scmp.com/comment/opinion/article/3229780/how-thailand-can-draw-closer-china-despite-us-rivalry-and-geopolitical-tensions?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.08.05 03:30;
;;

;July 1 marked the 48th anniversary of the formalisation of Sino-Thai relations. Today, China is Thailand's largest trading partner with US$135 billion of trade last year, about 18 per cent of Thailand's total.

;

;Thai exports to China have also jumped, from just US$1.82 billion in 1995 to US$37.7 billion in 2021, a testament to China's burgeoning middle class and Thailand's growing competitiveness as a manufacturing and agricultural powerhouse.

;

;With their cultural and interpersonal ties, a clear preference among Chinese households for holidaying in Thailand and joint venture successes from healthcare to cutting-edge start-ups and innovation, both countries have long enjoyed a synergy from the pooling of their capital, talent and knowledge.

;

;The Belt and Road Initiative has yielded considerable success in advancing regional infrastructural development through Thailand – an effective Southeast Asian heartland connecting China with Laos, Myanmar, Cambodia and Malaysia via a sophisticated train and logistical network.

;

;While receiving a Chinese delegation earlier this year, Pheu Thai Party leader Chonlanan Srikaew pledged to “drive more trade agreements, promote investment, mutual import-export, tourism as well as the exchange of technology”.

;

;Yet for Sino-Thai ties to meaningfully deepen, broaden and weather the coming decades, Beijing and Bangkok must address the elephant in the room: incipient geopolitical tensions largely stemming from the Sino-US rivalry.

;

;First, Thailand has sought to deepen military coordination with China while maintaining its deep military and defence ties with the US as a major non-Nato ally. This approach coheres with Thailand's “bamboo diplomacy”, an outlook that favours careful balancing between great powers and a staunch defence of national interests.

;

;Yet, as Washington increasingly applies pressure on Southeast Asian nations to pick sides in what it construes as a shoring-up of its regional influence against potential challenges from China, Thailand may be forced to choose.

;

;The recent and ongoing series of joint military exercises reflect the shared intentions of Beijing and Bangkok to neutralise regional conflicts and tensions, yet they are taking place against a background of renewed American interest in courting Southeast Asia.

;

;For Sino-Thai military cooperation to continue, a clear delineation of the remit and limits of the Thai military's relationship with both its US and Chinese counterparts is needed. More constructively, the incoming Thai cabinet should capitalise on the country's historical ties with both Beijing and the Tatmadaw, Myanmar's military, to seek a Sino-Asean-brokered peace deal to restore a modicum of democracy to Myanmar.

;

;Second, Thailand should position itself as a safe haven for investment amid the increasing Balkanisation of the global financial and supply chains. The war in Ukraine has kick-started a cascade of reorientations by multinational corporations and assets, with many moving from China to Southeast Asia in search of greater policy certainty.

;

;Small and medium-sized enterprises in Northeast Asia concerned by the potential fallout from military tensions in the Taiwan Strait have been eyeing Thailand as a cheaper, more regionally connected production base. Such divestment incentives also apply to Chinese companies looking for fertile ground for growth, both domestically and abroad.

;

;Thailand is no stranger to Chinese state-owned enterprises, such as SAIC Motor, which has teamed up with Charoean Pokphand Group to leverage Thailand as a hub of product internationalisation.

;

;Thailand's Eastern Economic Corridor also provides a prime opening for the diversification efforts of companies abroad. Similarly, Thai manufacturers must invest in developing greater resilience and self-sufficiency in the face of potential flare-ups that could disrupt the supply of critical minerals and other raw materials.

;

;Key policymakers in Thailand can tap the country's vast rare earth resources. Beijing should in turn ensure its joint ventures in Thailand remain sanction-proof and robust amid the precipitous weaponisation of finance in global geopolitics.

;

;Finally, at the core of any healthy bilateral relationship lie genuine and grounded people-to-people exchanges. Thailand was among the first countries that China resumed post-Covid group tours to, with Anutin Charnvirakul, the deputy prime minister and public health minister, greeting Chinese visitors at Suvarnahumi Airport in January.

;

;While Thai businesses have largely profited from the astronomical rise in China's purchasing power and Chinese markets over the past few decades, some argue that such dividends have not trickled down to the lower-middle and working classes.

;

;China's “zero-dollar” tourists had a lukewarm local response owing to the tour groups' concentrated spending, which mostly goes back to Chinese operators. The multiplier effect is clearly not working.

;

;Tensions between the Thai population and Chinese visitors could well arise due to many factors, including economically rooted resentment, but also stereotypes, religious disagreements or an increasingly politicised media space where portrayals of China's rise are often swayed by vested interests.

;

;Chinese tourists in Thailand face jail for stepping on coral, touching starfish

;

;The Thai government must strive to ensure its media outlets remain free from foreign interference and that coverage of its relationships with the US and China alike remains balanced, candid and fact-oriented. Beijing, on the other hand, must think prudently and critically about how China can gain even more trust, and win Thai hearts and minds.

;

;Hong Kong certainly has a role to play. With Chief Executive John Lee Ka-chiu making Thailand the destination for his first overseas trip last year, the city's special connections are clearly set to become increasingly important, as an additional conduit to China's relationship with Thailand.

;

;A win-win partnership awaits both China and Thailand, but key hurdles must first be overcome.

;After months of combing through more than 1,000 amendments, the US Senate finally passed its version of the National Defence Authorisation Act last week – and as has been the case in recent years, it was ripe with measures to counter China.

;

;The NDAA, legislation that establishes the top-line budget and directs policy for the Pentagon for the coming financial year, is a “must-pass” bill because its enactment is required for members of the military to receive their pay and benefits on time. As a result, provisions not strictly tied to defence often make it into the bill.

;

;The Democrat-led Senate passed its version by 86-11, while the Republican-led House narrowly passed its version earlier in July, 219-210.

;

;Reconciliation of the two into a single bill comes next, ahead of sending it to US President Joe Biden to sign into law, typically near the end of the year.

;

;

;

;With speculation rife that Chinese President Xi Jinping has ordered People's Liberation Army troops to be ready to take Taiwan by force by 2027, the self-ruled island has been increasingly featured in recent NDAAs.

;

;Both versions of the bill have many provisions dealing with Taipei's defence, including assessments of a blockade of fuel to China and other military options in the event of a PLA attack on Taiwan.

;

;And for the first time, the NDAA – at least in its House version – calls on the secretaries of State and Defence to maintain a non-combatant evacuation plan for Taiwan.

;

;US unveils US$345 million in military aid for Taiwan to help counter China

;

;Beijing regards Taiwan as a rogue province that must be eventually be united with the mainland, by force if necessary.

;

;Like most countries, the United States – Taiwan's biggest informal ally and arms supplier – does not recognise the island as an independent state. But Washington is committed by law to support Taiwan's military defence capability – a stance Beijing strongly opposes.

;

;Collin Koh, a research fellow at the S. Rajaratnam School of International Studies at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore, said that the numerous Taiwan-related provisions in the NDAA indicate a congressional convergence on the likelihood of a conflict with Beijing.

;

;“Such new measures appear to have given a more ominous signal of those anxieties,” he said.

;

;In addition to requesting an overall assessment of Taiwan's defence needs and US military readiness for war, the House version of the bill seeks a feasibility analysis of a US naval blockade of fossil fuels to China in the event of armed conflict.

;

;The Senate version requires a risk analysis of a sustained Chinese military blockade of the island, as well as a report on the “range of geopolitical and economic consequences” of a conflict in 2030.

;

;It would double the frequency of Pentagon briefings to Congress on Beijing's military posture from annually to every six months.

;

;Building on similar measures in last year's NDAA, the Senate bill would also establish a “comprehensive” training, advising, and institutional capacity-building programme for Taiwan's military – the better to improve Taiwan's ability to defend itself.

;

;Mainland China airs documentary signalling preparation for Taiwan attack

;

;For its part, the House bill wants the Pentagon to consider establishing a combined US-Taiwan military planning group.

;

;It also calls on the defence secretary to invite Taiwan to the US-led Rim of the Pacific (RIMPAC) military exercises within 30 days of the bill's enactment – setting a deadline for the invitation for the first time.

;

;RIMPAC, the world's largest maritime exercise – involving vessels from more than two dozen navies – has been held every other year since 1992 without Taiwan, despite previous legislative calls to include the island.

;

;And for the first time, both bills call for cybersecurity cooperation with Taiwan to “actively defend military networks, infrastructure and systems”.

;

;In recent months, Taipei has accused Beijing of increasing its cyberattacks at the island, and The New York Times has reported that the Biden administration has directed a search for hidden malware that could interrupt US military operations in the event of a conflict with China.

;

;But as with previous years, the bills largely avoid measures that explicitly challenge the US's one-China policy, in which Washington “acknowledges” Beijing's position that Taiwan is part of China.

;

;The House bill includes a provision barring the Pentagon from funding any map that depicts “Taiwan, Kinmen [also known as Quemoy], Matsu, Penghu, Wuciou, Green Island or Orchid Island as part of the territory of the People's Republic of China”.

;

;But this provision contradicts recent US government guidance on maps and is likely to be diluted, as happened last year with a similar proposal in a funding bill for the State Department.

;

;Hu Bo, a maritime strategy specialist at Peking University, said that the congressional efforts to bolster Taiwan reflected the Pentagon's “continuous” effort to engage the island, including by increasing the presence of US troops there.

;

;Blackpink, Barbie and Beijing's South China Sea claims collide in Vietnam

;

;“Recently, Washington seemingly wants to reduce the attention and sensitivity regarding Taiwan issues,” Hu added, suggesting that the Pentagon intends “to do more and say less”.

;

;Analysts also question the practicality of some of the proposals.

;

;Oriana Skylar Mastro, a fellow at Stanford University's Freeman Spogli Institute for International Studies, called an energy blockade by the US “very feasible” but was sceptical since any PLA attack would likely occur too quickly for such a move to work.

;

;“If China finds itself in a protracted war with the US in which that might come into play, it's already in trouble,” said Mastro, who is also a non-resident senior fellow at the Washington-based American Enterprise Institute.

;

;

;

;The NDAA drafts also focus on efforts to check Beijing's technological advancement.

;

;The Senate bill requires US businesses to notify the Treasury Department before investing in Chinese technologies like advanced semiconductors, artificial intelligence, quantum information science and hypersonics, areas crucial to the development of military capabilities.

;

;Senator Bob Casey, a Pennsylvania Democrat who is a cosponsor of the measure, said that it “would shed visibility on US investments going to China in highly sensitive and critical sectors”.

;

;The White House is expected to release an executive order on outbound investment later this month, which is likely to focus on similar sectors.

;

;Responding to the Senate proposal last week, Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman Mao Ning said: “Arbitrarily placing curbs for normal investment activities in the industrial community and private sectors violates the principle of market economy, disrupts the global industrial and supply chains and will only end up hurting the US investors.”

;

;The House bill calls for the Pentagon's annual China Military Power report to include an assessment of emerging technological developments by Beijing.

;

;And both versions take aim at funding towards Beijing, with prohibitions against Pentagon financing research in China, including at the Wuhan Institute of Virology, and the EcoHealth Alliance, a US-based non-profit that has partnered with the Wuhan institute.

;

;A Senate proposal to keep Chinese firms out of a federal government investment plan was cut, however.

;

;

;

;As with previous years, restricting Chinese influence in the US remains a focal point.

;

;The Senate bill bans entities from China, Russia, Iran and North Korea entities from purchasing American farmland and agricultural businesses – which the sponsoring legislators justified by using food security and espionage claims.

;

;The same amendment calls for adding the Secretary of Agriculture to the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS) – the inter-agency committee that screens inbound foreign investment.

;

;DeSantis signs bills limiting Chinese land ownership, TikTok at schools

;

;The House bill includes a measure that would require researchers financed by the Pentagon to disclose personal information like their nationality and educational background – a move that the White House strongly opposes, criticising it for adding administrative burdens, creating “an inadvertent national security risk” and likely deterring the Pentagon's ability “to attract the best and brightest foreign scientists”.

;

;Several House measures hope to block Chinese ideological influence, including one that prohibits Pentagon support for films that have been censored by China.

;

;Both versions target Confucius Institutes, which would effectively close all existing institutes in the US by 2026.

;

;

;

;Both the Senate and House bills also bolster existing regional security initiatives in the Indo-Pacific.

;

;The Senate version supports programmes like a maritime domain awareness initiative with regional allies – including Australia, Japan and India – and the Indo-Pacific Campaigning Initiative, which would increase the frequency of US military exercises and partner engagements in the region.

;

;The Senate bill leaves out language that would fast track the transfer of nuclear-powered submarines to Australia, part of an effort to persuade the Biden administration – which has already committed to providing such submarines to its Aukus ally – to invest more in domestic production before sending them abroad.

;West African defence chiefs have made a plan for potential military intervention to reverse last week's coup in Niger, including how and when to deploy forces, a leader of the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) said on Friday.

;

;The regional bloc will not divulge to the coup plotters when and where it will strike.

;

;That decision that will be taken by the heads of states, said Abdel-Fatau Musah, ECOWAS commissioner for political affairs, peace and security.

;

;“All the elements that will go into any eventual intervention have been worked out here, including the resources needed, the how and when we are going deploy the force,” he said at the close of a three-day meeting in Nigeria's capital Abuja.

;

;ECOWAS has already imposed sanctions on Niger and said it could authorise the use of force if the coup leaders do not restore power to elected President Mohamed Bazoum by Sunday.

;

;Niger coup: what would West African bloc's threat to use force look like?

;

;The 15-member body sent a delegation to Niger on Thursday seeking an “amicable resolution”, but a source in the entourage said a meeting at the airport with the junta's representatives yielded no breakthrough.

;

;“We want diplomacy to work, and we want this message clearly transmitted to them that we are giving them every opportunity to reverse what they have done,” Musah said.
